The aim of this study is to develop novel and an efficient bifunctional heterogeneous catalyst based on the SnO2 @Mn-ZIF core shell support decorated with Tungstophosphoric acid (TPA) active moieties. The designed catalyst was characterized with Thermal Gravimetric analysis (TGA/DTA), X-Ray Diffraction analysis (XRD), Scanning Electron Microscopy (SEM), Energy Dispersive X-Ray (EDX) analysis, Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FT-IR), Brunauer Emmet Teller (BET) analysis and Temperature Programmed Desorption of ammonia (NH3–TPD) and carbon dioxide (CO2–TPD) for structural and morphological investigation. Effect of crucial parameters such as methanol to oil molar ratio, reaction temperature, reaction time, agitation speed and catalyst dosage were thoroughly studied to develop profitable biodiesel process. The results indicated that Tungstophosphoric acid was well dispersed on the surface of the support. Further, it was noted that the catalyst with 30 wt% Tungstophosphoric acid onto the support formulation provided maximum biodiesel yield of 91.5 % under optimum reaction conditions of 6 wt% catalyst dosage with 18:1 methanol to oil molar ratio, 500 rpm stirring speed and reaction temperature of 100 °C for 3 h. Finally the designed catalyst experienced profound stability and was recycled up to five times for biodiesel production without any prior treatment. Graphical Abstract ga1 Keywords Feedstock Bifunctional heterogeneous catalyst Zeolitic imidazolate framework Reusability 1 Introduction The increasing energy demand has prompted the scientific community to hunt for sustainable energy resources which can efficiently replace the fossil-derived fuels in the near future. Fossil fuels are the main sources of energy all over the world. However, these conventional energy sources are predicted to run out due to their limited resources. Secondly, the energy demand has increased alarmingly due to rapid population growth and industrialization [1] Numerous renewable energy sources, including wind, solar, hydro, and biofuels have been recognized as a possible alternative to supplement the existing fossil fuels. Recently, biodiesel has been identified as a promising alternative to the conventional diesel due to its unique properties such as high combustion efficiency, high flash point, biodegradability, eco-friendliness, lubricity, non-toxicity, and adaptability for usage in existing vehicles [2-4]. The cost of biodiesel is the main obstacle for the production of biodiesel on the commercial scale. It has been identified that the cost of biodiesel is mainly dependent on the feedstock and the catalyst system. Feedstock is considered to play a pivotal role to produce economical viable biodiesel production. Therefore it is essential to select suitable feedstock to develop sustainable biodiesel production. In this context, Mazari palm (Nannorrhops ritchiana) seeds oil could be a very potential feedstock for large scale biodiesel production in economical way. Mazari palm plants are naturally found on large areas (mountainous) of Pakistan. Mazari palm seeds contain about 15 % oil content and therefore can contribute significantly towards the green energy in Pakistan’s energy mix. Recently, the production of biofuels from waste has gained promising interest in the scientific community. The huge amounts of seeds of these plants are degraded every year without any proper use. Therefore the utilization of these waste seeds can contribute efficiently towards the country economy and reduce the dependency on the import of foreign fuels [5]. Secondly, catalyst is also one of the most important factors to affect the cost of the biodiesel production. Currently, heterogeneous catalysts are touted as a viable option for clean biodiesel synthesis through the transesterification reaction. The recyclability with fewer disposal issues, non-corrosive, readily separated, and having higher selectivity with longer catalyst life are the key advantages of the heterogeneous catalysts [6-8]. Various SnO2 and Zeolitic imidazolate framework (ZIF) based heterogeneous catalysts such as SO4 2−/Al2O3–SnO2 [9], sulfonated SnO2 nanocatalyst [10], MoO3/SnO2 [11], lipase@ZIF-67 [12], (KNa/ZIF-8) [13], have been studied for the transesterification reaction of different feedstocks for biodiesel production. However, various process problems such as leaching, low stability, higher reaction time, lower reaction activity, high alcohol-to-oil molar ratio are reported to encounter with the current heterogeneous catalyst system used for biodiesel production [6]. Therefore, it is also important to design a potential catalyst for profitable biodiesel production. In the present studies, Tungstophosphoric acid active moieties were successfully decorated onto the SnO2@Mn-ZIF support to develop a novel bifunctional heterogeneous catalyst with enhanced catalytic activity in the biodiesel production from Mazari palm oil. Moreover, the physical and chemical properties of the catalyst were investigated to identify suitable catalyst formulation for efficient biodiesel production from the selected feedstock. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Chemicals All chemicals such as SnCl4.5H2O, 2-methyl imidazol (C4H6N2), Mn(NO3)2.4H2O, sodium polystyrenesulfonate (PSS), potassium hydroxide, Hexane, methanol and ethanol used in this research work were extra pure and used without further purification. 2.2 Catalyst preparation SnO2 microsphere were synthesized by the hydrothermal method as reported in the literature [14]. Similarly, Mn-ZIF was synthesized at room temperature following the procedure in the literature [15]. The SnO2@Mn-ZIF core shell support was synthesized as followed, Typically, 1 g of SnO2 microsphere was dispersed in 1 % of sodium polystyrenesulfonate (PSS) aqueous solution and stirred for 1 h at room temperature. The Mn-ZIF precursor solution consisting of 1.6 g of Mn(NO3)2 4 H2O, 4.2 g of 2-methylimidazole and 160 mL of methanol under stirring were then carefully added to the above mixture. The reaction was allowed to proceed for 24 h at room temperature so that the Mn-ZIF shell can grow uniformly on the SnO2 microsphere. Later, the product was centrifuged at 6000 rpm for 30 min and washed several times with methanol and dried at 60 ℃ overnight. 2.3 Decoration of Tungstophosphoric acid active moieties onto the SnO2@Mn-ZIF support Wet impregnation method was followed to graft the Tungstophosphoric acid moieties onto the SnO2@Mn-ZIF support to develop bifunctional heterogeneous catalyst for biodiesel production from Mazari palm oil. Typically, aqueous solution of 0.1 g of Tungstophosphoric acid was impregnated onto 0.9 g of SnO2@Mn-ZIF support to develop catalyst with 10 wt% TPA loading. The above solutions were then sonicated for 3 h to ensure well-distribution of the active moieties onto the support surface. The catalyst sample was later dried at 100 ℃ to eliminate the water. Similarly, catalysts with 20 and 30 wt% loading onto the SnO2@Mn-ZIF support were also prepared by the above procedure. 2.4 Characterization of the catalysts Different analytical techniques such as Thermogravimetric/Differential Thermal Analysis (TG/DTA) (model Perkin Elmer Pyris V-3.810), X-ray Diffraction (XRD) (model JEOL X-ray diffractometer), Scanning Electron Microscopy (SEM) (model JEOL, JSM 5910), Energy Dispersive X-Ray (EDX), Fourier Transform Infrared Spectrometry (FT-IR) (model SHIMADZU. 8201PC), Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) (model Micromeritics ASAP 2020) and Temperature Programmed Desorption of ammonia (NH3–TPD) and carbon dioxide (CO2–TPD) (model Thermo Scientific TPD 1100 with a TCD detector) were used for the characterization of the catalysts. Thermal gravimetric and derivative of thermal gravimetric (TG-DTG) analysis was performed on Perkin Elmer Pyris V-3.81 from room temperature to 1000 ℃ at a heating rate of 10 ℃ min−1 in the flow of N2 gas at 20 mL/min. X-ray diffractions (XRD) were performed on JEOL X-ray diffractometer, model JDX – 3532 with Mn filtered Cu-Kα radiations source in the range of the 2θ= 5º to 2θ= 80º. The morphology of the catalysts was determined by using the scanning electron microscopy model JSM 5910 (JEOL Co Japan) at 20 keV. The elemental composition for the synthesized catalyst was analyzed with an energy dispersive X-ray (SHIMADZU EDX 720) using rhodium X-ray source tube. Fourier transform infrared spectrophotometer (model SHIMADZU 8201 PC) was used to determine the various bands related to the functional groups of the catalysts. N2 adsorption-desorption analysis was performed on Micromeritics ASAP 2020 at − 196 ℃. The samples were first degassed at 200 ℃ for 4 h. Surface area was calculated using Brunauer-Emmett-Teller method (BET). The average pore size diameter and the pore size distribution of catalysts were calculated from the desorption isotherms data using Barret-Joyner-Halenda (BJH) method. The acidity and basicity characteristics of the synthesized catalysts were measured by Temperature Programmed Desorption (TPD) technique using NH3 and CO2 as probe molecules using Thermo Scientific TPD/R/O 1100 instrument. The catalyst samples were first treated with constant flow of nitrogen at 250 ℃ for 30 min. Later the chemisorptions of the probe molecules (NH3 and CO2) was performed by flowing NH3/CO2 (30 mL/min for 1 h). The catalyst surface was flushed later by purging helium for 15 min. Finally, the desorption of the probe molecules was carried out in the temperature range of 30–800 ℃ in the presence of helium as a carrier gas at 10 ℃/min. 2.4.1 Acidity determination of the catalyst The acidity characteristics of the fresh and used catalyst were investigated by titrometric method as reported elsewhere [16]. Typically, 0.2 g of the desired catalyst was dispersed in 40 mL of 2 molar NaCl solutions. The solution was agitated at room temperature for 24 h to change the equilibrium of the Na+ and H+ ions on the surface of the catalyst. Later, the mixture was filtered and the filtrate was titrated with 10 mmol/L solution of NaOH. The acid density of the catalyst was calculated using the following formula, (1) Acid density of the catalyst = CV m where C represents the concentration of NaOH solution, V represents the volume of NaOH solution used, and m represents the amount of the catalyst dispersed. 2.5 Transesterification reaction protocol The selected Mazari palm oil was employed as a feedstock for biodiesel production using the synthesized catalyst. The transesterification reaction was performed in 250 mL glass reactor under pre-determined reaction conditions. The catalyst was recovered from the reaction mixture by the centrifugation. The liquid portion was transferred to the separating funnel and allowed for 24 h to separate the different phases. The biodiesel layer was carefully collected and dried in oven at 80 ℃ for 2 h to eliminate the water content. The biodiesel yield was calculated using the formula as reported elsewhere [17,18]. (2) Biodiesel Yield ( % ) = weight of Biodiesel weight of Oil x 100 Moreover, the ester contents were determined by GC-MS analysis using the following formula [19], (3) FAME contents % = ∑ A − A s A s x Cs − Vs m x 100 ∑A = total peak areas of methyl ester present in the mixture. AS = area under the peak of internal standard (methyl octanoate). CS = concentration (mg/mL) of methyl octanoate solution. m = mass of the sample. VS = represent the volume of methyl octanoate solution used. The synthesized biodiesel was further characterized according to American Society for Testing and Materials (ASTM) and European Union (EN) to investigate the compatibility of the synthesized biodiesel. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterization of the catalyst 3.1.1 Thermal gravimetric analysis (TGA-DTA) The thermal stability of the synthesized Mn-ZIF was examined using Thermal gravimetric analysis (TGA-DTA). The thermal gravimetric analysis of the Mn-ZIF shows three decomposition temperatures as shown in Fig. 1a. The initial weight loss that occurred in temperature range of 138 ℃ and 175 ℃ could be attributed to the evaporation of adsorbed water and methanol molecules. The major weight loss, observed in the temperature range of 480–523 ℃, could be ascribed to the steady Mn-ZIF decomposition to final product [20,21]. However, the breakdown of the organic linkers is completed at around 800 ℃. Above 800 ℃, no significant weight loss in the sample was recorded. On the other hand, TGA–DTG analysis of SnO2@Mn-ZIF shows two endothermic peaks at 153 ℃ and 450 ℃. The endothermic peak at 153 ℃ is ascribed to the evaporation of absorbed water and methanol in the sample, whereas the endothermic peak at 450 ℃ is related to the breakdown of organic linkers in the sample. The weight loss above 500 ℃ is related to the breakdown of the remaining organic linkers in the sample. However, above 800 ℃ no significant weight loss occur showing that the sample has been decomposed to its stable compound [22,23]. Finally, the TGA–DTA analysis for the TPA decorated onto the SnO2@Mn-ZIF support was also performed as shown in Fig. 1c. The TG–DTA curves of the TPA 30 wt%/SnO2@Mn-ZIF showed two endothermic peaks at 200 ℃ and 800 ℃. The endothermic peak at 200 ℃ is ascribed to the evaporation of absorbed water, methanol and some of the organic linkers in the sample. The weight loss occurred over the temperature range of 300–800 ℃ can be ascribed to the decomposition of the TPA and remaining organic linkers in the sample. Further, the TGA–DTG curves show that there is no significant weight loss above 850 ℃, indicating that the breakdown of TPA/SnO2@Mn-ZIF has completed [23]. The TGA results verify that the SnO2@Mn-ZIF may be used as a catalyst in a wide range of temperature for biodiesel production. 3.1.2 X-ray diffraction (XRD) analysis The X-ray diffraction analysis was performed to gain the insight of the crystalline phase structure of the synthesized catalyst. The XRD pattern of the synthesized SnO2 ( Fig. 2a) shows various diffraction peaks at 2θ = 24°, 26.65°, 30.35°, 33.85°, 37.8°, 51.9° and 54.65°. These peaks confirm the tetragonal structure of the SnO2 sample [24]. The XRD pattern of the pure Mn-ZIF sample is depicted in Fig. 2b. The Mn-ZIF shows characteristic peaks at 7.25°, 10.1°, 12.5°, and 18.05°. The sharp peaks show the Mn-ZIF is well crystalline in nature [25]. Further, the XRD results confirm that Mn-ZIF was successfully synthesized at room temperature [26,27]. However, when Mn-ZIF was decorated onto the SnO2 microspheres, the XRD pattern presented characteristic peaks of SnO2 along with the characteristic peaks of Mn-ZIF (2θ= 7.25°, 12.7°, 18.05°, 26.65°, 30.35°, 33.85°, 37.8°, 51.9° and 54.65°), showing the successful decoration of the Mn-ZIF onto the SnO2 sphere [28]. Finally, the TPA decorated SnO2@Mn-ZIF catalyst were also characterized by XRD pattern as shown in Fig. 2. The XRD pattern shows various diffraction peaks appeared at 2θ= 7.25°, 12.7°, 18.05°, 26.65°, 30.35°, 33.85°, 37.8°, 51.9° and 54.65°. However, no characteristic peaks corresponding to TPA were recorded. Likewise, as the TPA concentration was increased, the intensity of the peaks corresponding to Mn-ZIF and SnO2 in the TPA/SnO2@Mn-ZIF catalyst were found to be slightly decreased, suggesting that the crystal structure of Mn-ZIF and SnO2 was altered. This may be due to the breakdown of the coordinate MnN bonds and the accumulation of TPA in the pores [29-31]. The Debye-Scherer formula was used to calculate the average crystallite size as shown in Table 1. The crystalline size slightly decreases upon TPA incorporation into the support. 3.1.3 Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) analysis Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) was used to examine the morphological characteristics of the catalyst. The SEM analysis of the SnO2 confirms the formation of well rounded, monodispersed SnO2 microsphere formation with smooth surface topography ( Fig. 3a). Similarly, the SEM images of the Mn-ZIF show that the particles are nanoscale in size, nearly spherical in shape, non-uniform and with little agglomeration. The SEM analysis of Mn-ZIF decorated SnO2 support show spherical morphology with little agglomeration and distribution of the Mn-ZIF crystallites over the SnO2 surface (Fig. 3c). Further, the SEM analysis revealed that the morphology of the SnO2 particle remained nearly unchanged after the loading of Mn-ZIF. Although, the surface become little rough due to the growth of Mn-ZIF onto the SnO2. On the other hand, TPA/SnO2@Mn-ZIF catalyst exhibits no definite shape. Further, the morphology of the synthesized catalyst was considerably changed as the TPA loading was increased [32]. The catalyst showed significant agglomeration when the TPA loading was enhanced onto the support. 3.1.4 Energy-dispersive X-ray (EDX) analysis The energy-dispersive X-ray (EDX) analysis was performed to investigate the elemental composition of the synthesized catalyst ( Fig. 4). The EDX analysis results revealed that all the essential elements were present in the catalyst matrix and desired amount, showing that the TPA modified SnO2@Mn-ZIF catalyst was successfully prepared without any elemental loss. The Mn-ZIF showed the elemental composition of C, N, and Mn with mass percentages of 33 %, 26 %, and 39 %, respectively. The existence of C, N, Sn, O and Mn elements in the SnO2@Mn-ZIF proves successful coating of the Mn-ZIF onto the SnO2 microsphere. 3.1.5 Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FT-IR) analysis Fourier Transform Infrared Spectroscopy (FT-IR) analysis was performed to identify the IR bands in synthesized catalyst in support of other characterization techniques. The IR spectrum of SnO2 display absorption peak at 619 cm−1, which is ascribed to Sn–O–Sn antisymmetric vibrations, whereas the peak at 520 cm−1 is related to Sn–O stretching vibrations [33,34]. The IR spectrum of the Mn-ZIF displays various absorption bands as shown in Fig. 5. The bands found in 1350–1500 cm−1 range are due to the stretching vibration of the imidazole ring. The bands detected between 900 and 1350 cm−1 might be related to the plane vibration of the imidazole ring. The bands at 500–800 cm−1 are ascribed to the imidazole ring out of plane vibration [35-37]. Thus, the FT-IR results show successful synthesis of the Mn-ZIF. The SnO2@Mn-ZIF core shell support depicts IR spectral bands at 1350–1500 cm−1, responsible for the stretching vibration of the imidazole ring. The bands detected between 900 and 1350 cm−1 might be related to the plane vibration of the imidazole ring. The bands at 500–800 cm−1 are ascribed to the imidazole ring out of plane vibration [35,37]. The characteristic band at 619 cm−1 is ascribed to Sn–O–Sn antisymmetric vibrations and the peak at 520 cm−1 is related to Sn–O stretching vibrations [33,34,38]. Thus, the IR results verify the successful decoration of the Mn-ZIF onto the SnO2 support. Similarly, the SnO2@Mn-ZIF decorated with TPA catalyst shows characteristic peaks at 610 cm−1, 481 cm−1, 1008 cm−1, 1037 cm−1, 1126 cm−1, 1162 cm−1 and 2983 cm−1. The peak at 619 cm−1 is ascribed to Sn–O–Sn antisymmetric vibrations, whereas the peak at 520 cm−1 is related to Sn–O stretching vibrations [33,34]. The bands found at 1350–1500 cm−1 are due to the stretching vibration of the imidazole ring. The bands found in the range 900 cm−1 and 1350 cm−1 might be related to the plane vibration of the imidazole ring. The bands at 500–800 cm−1 are ascribed to the imidazole ring out of plane vibration [35,37]. The absorption band at 2983 cm−1, arises from the stretching vibration of the CH bonds of methyl group and imidazolate ring. On the other hand, additional bands appear when the support is modified with TPA. The bands at 1081 cm−1, 982 cm−1, 889 cm−1, 797 cm−1 and 595 cm−1, are mainly related to the stretching vibrations of P–O, W=Ot, W–Oc–W, W–Oe–W, and the bending vibration of P–O, respectively [39,40]. 3.1.6 N2 adsorption-desorption (BET) analysis BET surface area and other essential textural characteristics of the synthesized catalyst were determined by N2-adsorption desorption technique. According to the results, Mn-ZIF exhibits the usual features of type-I isothermal curve as reported in the literature [41]. Secondly, a significant increase in the gas adsorption occurs in area of relatively low pressure, indicating the presence of micropores. Further, the horizontal plateaus show that the pores are already filled, with minimal subsequent adsorption. The specific surface area of Mn-ZIF is found to be 1351 m2/g with pore diameter (mostly concentrated) around 0.6 nm [42]. The synthesized SnO2@Mn-ZIF support shows type I and IV hybrid isotherms according to the IUPAC classification, indicating the coexistence of micropores and mesopores [43,44]. Moreover, the isotherm shows H4-type hysteresis loop at the relative pressure (P/Po) of 0.4–1.0. The pore size distribution determined by the Barrett-Joyner-Halenda (BJH) method is presented in inset of the Fig. 6. The SnO2@Mn-ZIF displays curve with two main peaks at 0.6 nm and 1.1 nm. The maximum BET surface area and micropore volume obtained for the SnO2@Mn-ZIF sample are 1387 m2/g and 0.58 cm3/g respectively. Similarly, the TPA/SnO2@Mn-ZIF catalyst also shows type I and IV hybrid isotherms according to the IUPAC classification showing the co-existence of the micropores and mesopores with H4-type hysteresis loop as shown in Fig. 6 [44]. The results clearly indicate that the co-ordination of Mn-N links in the Mn-ZIF disrupted upon the incorporation of the TPA active moieties. As a result, some micropores became mesopores, reducing sample micropore area while increasing the external surface area and average pore size. However, when the TPA loading was increased, the TPA molecules are supposed to enter the Mn-ZIF and accumulated in the pores, lowering the BET surface area and total pore volume. Over all, the surface area slightly decreased as TPA was decorated onto the surface of the support. This decrease is resulted from the blockage of the pores of support by the TPA molecules ( Table 2). 3.1.7 Acidity characteristics of the catalyst Temperature Programmed Desorption of ammonia (NH3-TPD) was performed to evaluate the acid sites distribution on the surface of the synthesized catalyst as given in Fig. 7 and Table 3. The SnO2@Mn-ZIF support shows strong acidic sites at temperature of 650 ℃. On the other hand, when SnO2 @Mn-ZIF was impregnated with TPA, the strong acid sites on the SnO2 @Mn-ZIF disappeared, whereas the intensity of the peak corresponding to the medium acid sites increased relatively [45,46]. The small shoulder peak at 300 ℃ is attributed to the acid sites of medium strength on the catalyst surface. Whereas, the broad peak centered at 400 ℃ is attributed to the co-existence of medium and strong acid sites. On the other hand, the shoulder peak appeared at 470 ℃ is dedicated to the existence of strong acid sites on the surface of the catalyst. The NH3-TPD results further demonstrate that the percentage of medium acid sites increases with increasing the TPA loading onto the SnO2@Mn-ZIF. Among different TPA/SnO2@Mn-ZIF supported catalysts, 30 wt% TPA decorated SnO2@Mn-ZIF catalyst shows greater percentage of medium acid sites and less number of strong acid sites on the surface. The co-existence of medium and strong acid sites on the surface of the catalyst may contribute towards the high efficiency in the biodiesel production from the selected feedstock. 3.1.8 Basicity characteristics of the catalyst Carbon dioxide Temperature Programmed Desorption (CO2-TPD) was used to study the basic sites distribution on the surface of the catalyst as shown in Fig. 8 and Table 4. The CO2-TPD pattern of the SnO2@Mn-ZIF support shows the presence of only strong basic sites at temperature 700 ℃ [47]. On the other hand, the TPA decorated SnO2@Mn-ZIF catalysts shows the distribution of basic sites of different strengths. All the catalysts show medium strength basic sites at temperature 250–400 ℃ and strong acid sites at temperature 470 ℃. Similarly, very strong acid sites appeared at temperature 570 ℃. It is interesting that TPA loading does not affect the distribution of the acid sites. However, the number of medium and strong basic sites increased when TPA loading was increased. [48]. Among different TPA/SnO2@Mn-ZIF supported catalysts, TPA 30 wt% decorated SnO2@Mn-ZIF catalyst shows greater percentage of medium and strong basic sites on the surface as given in Table 4. 3.2 Catalytic activity evaluation Similarly, the catalytic activity of the various TPA decorated SnO2@Mn-ZIF catalyst was evaluated in the biodiesel production under reaction conditions of oil/methanol molar ratio 1:10, catalyst loading of 3 wt%, reaction time of 2 h, reaction temperatures of 70 ℃ and agitation speed of 400 rpm. The activity results evidently showed that the SnO2@Mn-ZIF catalyst decorated with 30 wt% TPA active moieties showed best catalytic performance and provided maximum biodiesel yield of 47 %. Based on the experimental results, TPA 30 wt%/SnO2@Mn-ZIF catalyst was further considered. The various parameters such as oil/methanol molar ratio, reaction temperatures, concentration of catalyst, reaction time, and agitation speed were studied in detail as follow ( Fig. 9). 3.3 Optimization of various reaction parameters 3.3.1 Effect of methanol to oil molar ratio Methanol is one of the important reagents in the biodiesel reaction. Therefore, play an important role to push the transesterification reaction in the forward direction [49]. The effect of methanol on the biodiesel yield was investigated as shown in Fig. 10. It is clearly shown that biodiesel yield significantly increases as the methanol amount was increased and that the maximum yield of 54 % was obtained at 1:18. This shows that 1:18 molar ratio is suffice to enhance the forward reaction rate and provide the maximum biodiesel yield. However, further increase in the oil to methanol molar ratio above 1:18, biodiesel yield was decreased sufficiently [50-52]. The decrease might be due to the increase in the solubility of glycerol in excess methanol which facilitates the backward reaction. Secondly, the separation also becomes a problem while using more methanol. In the view of the above, 1:18 oil to methanol molar ratio was considered to be the optimum for biodiesel production. 3.3.2 Effect of reaction temperature Similarly, reaction temperature plays significant role in the transesterification reaction to produce economical viable biodiesel production. The effect of temperature on the transesterification reaction of Mazari palm oil using the TPA 30 wt%/SnO2@Mn-ZIF catalyst was thoroughly studied in the temperature range of 70–110 °C as shown in Fig. 11. It can be seen that at lower temperature only 48 % of the Mazari palm oil was converted into biodiesel. However, as the temperature was increased, the yield of biodiesel also increased, whereas, 83 % yield was obtained at 100 °C. Actually, the higher reaction temperature, enhance the reactant miscibility and molecular collision by overcoming the viscosity mass transfer limitations. However, further increase in temperature had adverse effect on biodiesel production, most likely due to the rapid evaporation of the methanol from the reaction mixture and bubble formation which reduce the accessibility of the reactants to the active sites. As a result, the biodiesel yield decreases. Thus, the 100 °C temperature was selected as the optimum reaction temperature in the current studies. 3.3.3 Effect of catalyst concentration Catalyst amount is one of the influential factors that affect the overall transesterification process. Secondly, the catalyst amount plays an important role in the process cost. Therefore, this parameter should properly be optimized to select suitable amount for the economical biodiesel production. It can be seen that the biodiesel yield significantly increased as the catalyst amount was increased [53]. This higher catalyst amount provides sufficient active sites for the reactants to push the reaction in the forward direction. However, when the catalyst loading was increased beyond 8 % the biodiesel yield was slightly lowered. This could be due to the fact that the higher catalyst amount may result in mixing problems [54,55] ( Fig. 12). 3.3.4 Effect of reaction time Similarly, reaction time is also important factor to develop sustainable and profitable biodiesel production process. Generally, the reaction is slow at the beginning due to mixing and dispersion of alcohol and oil. However, when the reaction time is increased, the biodiesel yield also increases. On the other hand, prolonged reaction may result in reversible reaction, resulting in a reduction in biodiesel yield [56]. In the present work, the effect of time on the biodiesel yield from the Mazari palm oil using the synthesized TPA/SnO2@Mn-ZIF catalyst was also investigated as illustrated in Fig. 13. It can be seen that maximum biodiesel yield can be achieved in the reaction time of 180 min this shows that reaction time of 180 min is enough for the reactants to interact properly with the active sites of the catalyst and covert efficiently into the final products. Moreover, this further demonstrates that the reaction reaches to its equilibrium position within this optimized time of 180 min. However, very long time may have adverse effect on the catalytic activity which may affect the biodiesel yield. Therefore 180 min were selected as optimum time to obtained profitable biodiesel production from Mazari palm oil using the synthesized catalyst [57]. 3.3.5 Effect of agitation speed In the case of heterogeneous catalysis, the reaction mixture is consisting of three phases in nature, i.e., oil-methanol-catalyst. As a result of three phase system, strong mass transfer limitations exist which render the forward reaction rate [58]. Therefore, proper agitation speed is required to overcome the mass transfer limitations and produce higher biodiesel yield. In the present work, the effluence of agitation speed on the biodiesel yield from the transesterification of Mazari palm oil in the presence of designed catalyst was also investigated as depicted in the Fig. 14. As can be seen from the results that the biodiesel yield increased as the agitation speed was increased and maximum biodiesel yield of 91.5 % was achieved at agitation speed of 500 rpm. However, when the agitation speed was further increased beyond 500 rpm, a decrease in biodiesel yield was recorded. Actually, the higher agitation speed decreases the availability of the required amount of the catalyst for the reactants to interact properly for sufficient time, thereby decreases the efficiency of the transesterification reaction. 3.3.6 Reusability of the synthesized catalyst The recyclability of the synthesized catalyst was investigated in the biodiesel production from the selected Mazari palm oil to determine its economical viability for sustainable biodiesel production. In the current study, the synthesized catalyst was found to be very efficient for three consecutive reaction cycles, providing biodiesel yield of more than 90 %. Further, it can be seen that the catalyst shows sufficient reusability up to five reaction cycles ( Fig. 15). However, the catalytic activity of the catalyst started to decline when used for more than 5 reaction cycles. The decrease in the catalytic activity is due to the accumulation of organic or carbonaceous components on the surface of the catalyst and hence blocks the active sites of the catalyst. It is important to mention that the catalyst used in each reaction cycle was only treated thermally at 100 ℃ in the oven prior to the testing. In addition, the activity of the deactivated catalyst was recovered by washing with methanol to flush the unwanted organic molecules deposited on the surface of the catalyst. Moreover, the synthesized biodiesel was also analyzed by atomic absorption spectroscopy (AAS) to investigate the leaching of the active phase from the catalyst surface during the reaction. The results clearly indicated that no trace elements of the catalyst active species were found in the biodiesel sample, which illustrate that no leaching of the active species from the catalyst surface has occurred. Moreover, the acidity tests were also performed by titrometric method to investigate the stability of the fresh and used catalyst ( Table 5) [15]. The results indicated that there was no significant change in the acid density for the fresh and used catalysts, showing that no leaking of the TPA active moieties from the surface occurred during the transesterification reaction. This further illustrate that the active moieties are firmly bounded to the surface of the support and hence prevent the leaching of the active species during the biodiesel production from the selected feedstock. The overall results summarized that the TPA/SnO2@Mn-ZIF catalyst has a promising capability to use for large scale biodiesel production from low cost Mazari palm oil in the near future. 3.4 Proposed mechanism The synthesized TPA decorated SnO2@Mn-ZIF catalyst presents different types of active sites i.e., Brønsted acid sites (the protons of –NH and TPA), Lewis acid sites (coordinatively unsaturated Manganese cations) and Lewis base sites (N- extremities of imidazolate ligands). During the biodiesel reaction, the Lewis acid sites catalyze the esterification of free fatty acids into esters. Similarly, the Brønsted acid sites catalyze the simultaneous esterification and transesterification of the free fatty acids and triglycerides respectively [15,59]. On the other hand, the Lewis base sites present on the catalyst surface produce reactive methoxy group, which later attack on the triglycerides to produce a tetrahedral intermediate. The intermediate immediately decompose to ester and di-glycerides. In the similar fashion, di-glycerides and mono-glycerides are also converted into respective products i.e., FAME and glycerol. The proposed mechanism is presented below ( Scheme 1). 3.5 Physiochemical properties of the biodiesel The fuel characteristics of the synthesized biodiesel were determined according to ASTM and EN methods as given in Table 6. It can be seen that the synthesized biodiesel shows interesting characteristics and fall within the range as defined by the ASTM and EN methods. The characteristics of the synthesized biodiesel indicate that the Mazari palm biodiesel is suitable to be used as a fuel in existing engine. This further confirms that the Mazari palm oil has been successfully converted into biodiesel using TPA 30 wt%/SnO2@Mn-ZIF catalyst. 4 Conclusion Tungstophosphoric acid decorated SnO2 @Mn-ZIF bifunctional heterogeneous catalyst was successfully synthesized for the transesterification of inexpensive Mazari palm seeds oil to develop sustainable biodiesel process. The various techniques such as Thermal Gravimetric analysis (TGA/DTA), X-Ray Diffraction analysis (XRD), Scanning Electron Microscopy (SEM), Energy Dispersive X-Ray (EDX) analysis, Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FT-IR), Brunauer Emmet Teller (BET) analysis and Temperature Programmed Desorption of ammonia (NH3–TPD) and carbon dioxide (CO2–TPD) were employed for the characterization of the synthesized catalyst. The results demonstrated that the active species are well dispersed on the support surface. Among different catalysts, TPA 30 wt%/SnO2@Mn-ZIF provided the highest biodiesel yield under the optimized conditions of 6 wt% catalyst dosage with 18:1 methanol to oil molar ratio, 500 rpm stirring speed and reaction temperature of 100 °C for 3 h. The selected catalyst also showed acceptable stability and reusability in five biodiesel reaction. Moreover, the physical, fuel and composition of the synthesized Mazari palm biodiesel comply with the ASTM and EN standards, hence can be used as a fuel in existing engine. coredata.dc:description: The aim of this study is to develop novel and an efficient bifunctional heterogeneous catalyst based on the SnO2 @Mn-ZIF core shell support decorated with Tungstophosphoric acid (TPA) active moieties. The designed catalyst was characterized with Thermal Gravimetric analysis (TGA/DTA), X-Ray Diffraction analysis (XRD), Scanning Electron Microscopy (SEM), Energy Dispersive X-Ray (EDX) analysis, Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FT-IR), Brunauer Emmet Teller (BET) analysis and Temperature Programmed Desorption of ammonia (NH3–TPD) and carbon dioxide (CO2–TPD) for structural and morphological investigation. Effect of crucial parameters such as methanol to oil molar ratio, reaction temperature, reaction time, agitation speed and catalyst dosage were thoroughly studied to develop profitable biodiesel process. The results indicated that Tungstophosphoric acid was well dispersed on the surface of the support. Further, it was noted that the catalyst with 30 wt% Tungstophosphoric acid onto the support formulation provided maximum biodiesel yield of 91.5 % under optimum reaction conditions of 6 wt% catalyst dosage with 18:1 methanol to oil molar ratio, 500 rpm stirring speed and reaction temperature of 100 °C for 3 h. Finally the designed catalyst experienced profound stability and was recycled up to five times for biodiesel production without any prior treatment.
coredata.dc:title: Biodiesel production from Mazari palm (Nannorrhops ritchiana) seeds oil using Tungstophosphoric acid decorated SnO2@Mn-ZIF bifunctional heterogeneous catalyst
